channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: The U.S. trade deficit ballooned 14% to a record $140.5 billion in March, as businesses stockpiled goods to get ahead of tariffs that President Trump imposed the following month
item.description: The deficit ballooned to $140.5 billion in March, as businesses stockpiled goods to get ahead of tariffs imposed the following month.
item.dc:creator: Anthony DeBarros

item.title: U.S. Could Collect More Than $100 Billion With Broader Tariffs, EU Trade Official Says
item.description: American officials are looking into potential tariffs for several sectors, citing national security, including on imports of copper and lumber as well as pharmaceuticals.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: French Industry Produced More Ahead of Tariffs
item.description: The industrial sector continued to book rising output, capping a positive start to a year that could nevertheless darken if U.S. trade tariffs bite into demand.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: China Services Sector Gauge Slips to Seven-Month Low Amid Trade Spat
item.description: A private gauge of China’s services sector signaled that activity slowed in April, as rising trade tension hurt new orders and market sentiment.

item.title: The Fed must confront difficult decisions this week on whether to defend against inflation or against an economic slowdown
item.description: The central bank is preparing for difficult judgments and emerging divisions regarding when to cut interest rates. Its two-day policy meeting is this week.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Investors worldwide have plenty of questions about the future of Berkshire Hathaway after Warren Buffett leaves the top job. The city of Omaha has some, too.
item.description: Despite the billionaire’s frugal ways, his presence pumped up the local economy, drawing tourists and packing annual conventions.
item.dc:creator: John McCormick

item.title: Major U.S. employers are starting to take a new approach to jobs: Hire less—or not at all
item.description: Most employers aren’t laying off workers, but many have paused hiring while the trade war plays out
item.dc:creator: Lauren Weber

item.title: The spring home-buying season is off to a slow start—but not everywhere
item.description: Markets in Florida and Texas with lots of inventory are posting the biggest price declines, while prices in the Northeast and Midwest are still rising.
item.dc:creator: Max Rust

item.title: Some small and midsize U.S. manufacturers are seeing an uptick in orders from companies looking to avoid new tariffs
item.description: Levies on imports are giving early boosts to some American factories.
item.dc:creator: Bob Tita

item.title: The U.S. labor market steadily added jobs last month despite jolting tariff announcements that many economists expect will give way to a trade policy-induced slowdown later this year
item.description: The labor market steadily added jobs despite tariff announcements that many economists expect will give way to a slowdown later this year.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Fed to Hold Rates, Could Signal Possible Cuts Ahead
item.description: A decision by the Federal Reserve will be the highlight of the coming week, with rates expected to be left on hold and markets expected to focus on the likelihood of rate cuts in coming months as trade tariffs take their toll on the economy.

item.title: President Trump is right to see global trade imbalances as a problem, writes Ed Conway. Can a proposed ’Mar-a-Lago Accord’ fix them?
item.description: The great economist John Maynard Keynes once proposed an international system to eliminate trade surpluses and deficits. Now the ‘Mar-a-Lago Accord’ aims to bring that idea to life.
item.dc:creator: Ed Conway

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Holds Close to Target, Lining Up New Rate Cuts to Counter Tariffs
item.description: Consumer-price inflation in the eurozone remained just above the ECB’s target, teeing up more interest-rate cuts as policymakers anticipate a hit to growth from higher U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: EU Could Offer to Buy $56 Billion of U.S. Products to End Trade War, Top Negotiator Says
item.description: Trump has repeatedly lambasted the EU for what he says are the unfair surpluses they run in their trade in goods with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: The April data on jobs and unemployment to be released Friday will give more information on the broader impact of President Trump’s tariffs than the quarterly GDP report did, columnist Greg Ip writes
item.description: Friday’s report will provide the first “hard” data since President Trump’s April 2 tariff announcements.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Heard on the Street: Home builders have been offering sweeteners including mortgage-rate buydowns, price cuts and design upgrades to try to entice buyers
item.description: Demand has been disappointing during the spring home-buying season, and tariffs threaten to raise costs.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: Beijing-Backed Accounts Hint at U.S. Outreach on Trade as China Keeps Door Open
item.description: Beijing-backed social media accounts say U.S. officials have reached out to Chinese counterparts through multiple channels to discuss trade, as the world watches for any sign of tariff talks between the two sides.
item.dc:creator: Jiahui Huang

item.title: The Bank of Japan halved its growth forecast for the Japanese economy as U.S. tariffs begin to bite
item.description: Japan is one of a handful of countries in talks with President Trump about averting steeper tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: South Korea’s Exports Unexpectedly Rose in April, Even as Trump Tariffs Pinch
item.description: South Korea’s exports unexpectedly expanded for a third consecutive month in April, even as President Trump’s sweeping tariffs have started to hurt international trade.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: The scramble to get goods to the U.S. ahead of President Trump’s tariffs has already led to huge distortions in global trade patterns and economic data. It isn’t over yet
item.description: The scramble to get goods to the U.S. ahead of President Trump’s tariffs has already led to huge distortions in global trade patterns and economic data. It isn’t over yet.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miao

item.title: Canada GDP Ticks Up After 0.2% Decline in February
item.description: After a solid performance in the second half of last year, and the strongest monthly growth in GDP in nine months in January, the economy is widely expected to be hit hard this year.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: U.S. Hiring Slows as Employers’ Concerns Mount, ADP Data Show
item.description: Hiring in the U.S. private sector slowed markedly in April, with 62,000 jobs created, down from 147,000 in March, according to the ADP National Employment report. The data missed economists’ forecasts.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Thai Central Bank Cuts Rates To Support Economy Amid Uncertainty
item.description: The Thai central bank cut its benchmark rate and flagged the possibility of slower economic growth, as ongoing global uncertainties cloud the Southeast Asian nation’s outlook.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Lee

item.title: Commodity Prices Set to Tumble as Tariffs Slow Global Economy
item.description: The World Bank said it expects commodity prices to fall sharply this year and next as rising tariffs lead to a slowdown in the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Ireland’s Economy Surges as U.S. Businesses Stockpile Ahead of Possible Tariffs
item.description: The economy surged as U.S. pharmaceutical giants based in the country boosted production to build stockpiles back home ahead of threatened tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Eurozone Business Sentiment Takes Hit From Tariffs
item.description: The services, industrial and construction sectors all saw worsening sentiment compared with March, as did consumer confidence.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Tariffs to Weaken Growth and Inflation, ECB’s Cipollone Says
item.description: Closer cooperation between countries that favor trade openness is needed to avoid worse outcomes for the global economy according to the senior official at the European Central Bank.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Heard on the Street: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all
item.description: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos

item.title: State and local governments rolled out the red carpet to federal workers who were laid off en masse this year, but many federal applicants are still waiting to get through the door
item.description: Soaring demand, red tape, and mismatched opportunities are frustrating some new job seekers.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: Americans are feeling gloomy about the economy after President Trump’s market-rattling first few months in office. But overall they are keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.description: People are still buying things at a steady clip, keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: American households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment
item.description: Households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: U.K. Consumers’ Mood Darkens Under Tariff Clouds
item.description: Consumers in the U.K. are growing more pessimistic as they fear the weight of trade tariffs and renewed high inflation, according to research group GfK.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Sales of existing homes in March posted their biggest monthly decline in more than two years
item.description: Many buyers, spooked by rising economic uncertainty, stayed away from the housing market during the start of the crucial spring season.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: The largest credit card companies are preparing for the economy to get worse.
item.description: Already, delinquencies are rising and are now in line with levels from before the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Imani Moise

item.title: Housing starts, a measure of home construction, dropped 11.4% in March from February, marking the steepest plunge in a year
item.description: Economic uncertainty and rising material costs from tariffs darken the outlook for newly built homes.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: The overbuilding of apartments suddenly looks like a lucky break for the multifamily industry—thanks to tariffs
item.description: The multifamily industry built more than one million new units, but now it can pause most construction ahead of potential tariffs on building materials.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto
